verses.text: Call now—will anyone answer you? And to which of the holy ones will you turn?
verses.comment: Eliphaz challenges Job to seek help from the holy ones, hinting at the need for mediation and intercession. This reflects the scriptural motif of asking the righteous to intercede (cf. James 5:16), subtly affirming the value of seeking spiritual intercession.

verses.text: For resentment kills the fool, and jealousy slays the simple.
verses.comment: A warning against the destructive power of resentment and envy. Echoes the spiritual teaching on the deadly consequences of vice and need for interior purification.

verses.text: I have seen a fool taking root, but suddenly his house was cursed.
verses.comment: Outward success is fleeting apart from God's blessing. This is a reminder of the frailty of worldly security and the importance of building life on a spiritual foundation.

verses.text: His children are far from safety; they are crushed in the gate, and there is no one to deliver them.
verses.comment: Legal protection fails for the wicked; this echoes concern for justice and the vulnerable—mirroring the call for communal responsibility for the weak (cf. Matt. 25:40).

verses.text: The hungry consume his harvest, even taking it from among thorns, and the thirsty pant after their wealth.
verses.comment: The loss of the wicked’s goods emphasizes social reversal as a divine principle. God's justice restores what was lost to the poor, foreshadowing themes of restoration seen in the Gospel (cf. Luke 1:53).

verses.text: For hardship does not come from the ground, nor does trouble spring from the soil.
verses.comment: Suffering is not random, but rather has a deeper purpose or cause—pointing to the mystery of suffering and divine providence, fulfilled and ultimately revealed in Christ’s own Passion.

verses.text: Yet man is born to trouble, as surely as sparks fly upward.
verses.comment: Human suffering is universal, pointing to the doctrine of original sin and our need for redemption. This theme is developed in Paul’s teachings (cf. Rom. 5:12).

verses.text: But as for me, I would seek God, and to Him I would present my case.
verses.comment: The emphasis on approaching God directly hints at both individual petition and the historical development of asking for spiritual aid—prayer as the means to approach God’s mercy.

verses.text: He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed, miracles that cannot be counted.
verses.comment: God’s works and miracles testify to His ongoing presence and revelation—foreshadowing the greater miracles performed by Christ Himself as ultimate sign of divine intervention.

verses.text: He gives rain on the earth and sends water to the fields.
verses.comment: God’s providence is expressed in natural blessings, which calls us to recognize both physical and spiritual nourishment—see Jesus promising living water (John 4:10–14).

verses.text: He sets the lowly up high and lifts those who mourn to safety.
verses.comment: Raising the humble is a recurring scriptural theme; see the Magnificat (Luke 1:52–53), showing God’s concern for the poor and afflicted—fulfilled in Christ’s own ministry.

verses.text: He frustrates the plans of the crafty, so their hands achieve no success.
verses.comment: God overturns the schemes of the wicked—echoing both Old and New Testament teachings that trust in human wisdom is futile without God. Paul draws on this theme in denouncing earthly wisdom.

verses.text: He catches the wise in their own craftiness, and the counsel of the cunning is swept away.
verses.comment: Directly quoted in Paul’s letter to the Corinthians, showing continuity between old wisdom literature and new apostolic teaching. Divine wisdom humbles human pride.

verses.text: They meet with darkness in the daytime, and grope at noon as if it were night.
verses.comment: Spiritual blindness as a result of sin and pride illustrates a motif of judgment. Jesus often speaks of those who have eyes but do not see.

verses.text: But He saves the needy from the sword, from their mouth, and from the hand of the mighty.
verses.comment: God is protector of the poor, echoing the Psalms. This theme of deliverance prefigures Christ’s ministry to the oppressed.

verses.text: So the poor have hope, and injustice shuts its mouth.
verses.comment: Restoration and hope for the poor signal the ultimate defeat of evil—see Mary’s proclamation in the Gospel and the closing of mouths echoing final judgment.

verses.text: Behold, blessed is the one whom God reproves; so do not despise the discipline of the Almighty.
verses.comment: God’s discipline signifies His love and leads to spiritual growth (see Hebrews 12 and Proverbs); embracing divine correction as a path to holiness is a sign of spiritual maturity.

verses.text: For He wounds, but He also binds up; He strikes, but His hands heal.
verses.comment: God’s chastisement and healing highlight His mercy—foreshadowing the wounds and healing brought by Christ’s own suffering, and the sacramental imagery of restoration.

verses.text: He will deliver you from six troubles; in seven, no evil will touch you.
verses.comment: The use of ‘six’ and ‘seven’ signifies complete protection; symbolic of God’s perfect care over His people through all adversities.

verses.text: In famine He will redeem you from death, and in battle from the power of the sword.
verses.comment: Deliverance from famine and war point to God’s saving work, with a spiritual dimension fulfilled in Christ’s victory over sin and death.

verses.text: You will be protected from the scourge of the tongue, and you will not fear destruction when it comes.
verses.comment: Protection extends also to slander, showing God’s care over both physical and spiritual threats—relates to Jesus defending His followers from spiritual peril.

verses.text: You will laugh at destruction and famine, and you will not fear the wild animals of the earth.
verses.comment: Joy in the face of disaster indicates trust in divine providence, suggesting the peace that surpasses understanding, promised in Christ (Phil. 4:7).

verses.text: You will be in covenant with the stones of the field, and the wild animals will be at peace with you.
verses.comment: Harmony in creation foreshadows the messianic peace (Isaiah 11)—the restoration of all things in Christ, signaling a universal reconciliation.

verses.text: You will know that your tent is secure; you will inspect your home and nothing will be missing.
verses.comment: Security at home is both a literal and spiritual promise, pointing to peace and stability as gifts of faith and spiritual order—the household as a blessed community.

verses.text: You will know that your descendants will be many, and your offspring like the grass of the earth.
verses.comment: Blessings of progeny reaffirm God’s fidelity to His promises; see Abrahamic covenant—ultimately fulfilled in Christ and His spiritual family.

verses.text: You will go to the grave in full strength, like a sheaf gathered in its season.
verses.comment: A good death signifies the completion of a faithful life—a theme mirrored in Christian teaching about perseverance and dying in grace; hints at the hope of resurrection for the faithful.

verses.text: Behold, this we have examined and it is true. Hear it, and apply it to yourself.
verses.comment: Eliphaz concludes with an exhortation to listen and learn—paralleling wisdom traditions in Scripture, inviting faithful application as a path to holiness and deeper union with God.
